perturbation.original_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Development Term”), each Party (the “Offering Party”) agrees to provide to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) a right of first offer with respect to any proposed offer or arrangement, which the Offering Party (or its affiliate) desires to accept, under which the Offering Party or one of its affiliates would acquire the ownership of real property in the Market Area (the “Development Property”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort would operate (a “Development Opportunity”).
perturbation.changed_text: During the period beginning on the Effective Date and ending on December 31, 2018 (the “Limited Term”), each Party (the “Presenting Party”) agrees to provide to the other Party (the “Accepting Party”) a courtesy consideration with respect to any potential offer or understanding, which the Presenting Party (or its affiliate) may consider, under which the Presenting Party or one of its associates might explore the utilization of immovable assets in the Market Area (the “Property”) on which a Hyatt All-Inclusive Resort could potentially function (a “Possible Venture”).
perturbation.explanation: The change replaces established legal terms like 'Development Term,' 'Offering Party,' 'Receiving Party,' 'Development Property,' and 'Development Opportunity' with vague, non-standard terms such as 'Limited Term,' 'Presenting Party,' 'Accepting Party,' 'Property,' and 'Possible Venture.' This creates ambiguity and renders the clause difficult to enforce due to the lack of clear legal definitions for the modified terms, conflicting with established real estate and contract law principles.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law, Real Estate Law, related to Offer and Acceptance

perturbation.original_text: If the Offering Party is required to offer the Receiving Party a Development Opportunity pursuant to this Section 1, the Offering Party must deliver written notice to the Receiving Party, together with reasonable due diligence information in the Offering Party’s possession to enable the Receiving Party to evaluate the Development Opportunity (collectively, the “Offer Notice”).
perturbation.changed_text: If the Presenting Party chooses to alert the Accepting Party to a Possible Venture related to this Section 1, the Presenting Party may dispatch a general correspondence to the Accepting Party, accompanied by some background details at the Presenting Party’s discretion so the Accepting Party can glance over the Potential Venture (referred to as “Suggestion Note”).
perturbation.explanation: The language is changed from 'written notice' to 'general correspondence,' 'reasonable due diligence information' to 'some background details at the Presenting Party’s discretion,' and 'Offer Notice' to 'Suggestion Note.' This significantly weakens the obligation to provide comprehensive information, making the due diligence process optional and vague, contradicting the standards expected in business transactions and potentially violating disclosure requirements.

perturbation.original_text: The Receiving Party will have ten (10) business days after receiving the Offer Notice to notify the Offering Party whether the Receiving Party exercises its right of first offer for that Development Opportunity.
perturbation.changed_text: The Accepting Party should endeavor to inform the Presenting Party within roughly two weeks following receipt of the Suggestion Note about their interest in the Potential Venture.
perturbation.explanation: The precise 'ten (10) business days' is replaced with an inexact 'roughly two weeks,' and the firm 'notify' with the suggestion 'should endeavor to inform.' The 'right of first offer' is implicitly changed to 'interest in the Potential Venture,' undermining the legal right with an expression of mere interest. This creates considerable uncertainty regarding timelines and obligations, conflicting with legal requirements for clear contract terms.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law, related to Timeliness and Obligation
